section.para:
General Error Correction (GEC) document
Financial Processing General Error Correction (GEC) document
Select/Acquire
> Others
> Donor Encumbered Report
> Donor Encumbered Report
If you add an amount to a Donor record, and then assign that Donor to PO line items, there are two screens that give you tracking information about encumbrances and expenditures:

listitem.para: Donor Encumbered Report
Annual Stewardship Report
For additional information about donor reports, see Donor Annual Stewardship Report

section.para: This “report” is actually a lookup screen, and is accessed from the Select & Acquire tab, Others submenu. This lookup looks at encumbrances and expenditures on PO line items associated with a given donor record.

mediaobject.alt: Donor Encumbered Report Lookup Screen with Sample Results

section.para: This example shows the donor code BRNO has received $500 so far this fiscal year. In May 2014, books totaling $56.75 were ordered on PO line items with the BRNO donor code. However, no invoices were paid in May using line items with this donor code.
In future releases, this report will be enhanced with additional bibliographic data, and with hyperlinks from the results to the relevant records.

section.title: General Ledger Introduction
section.para: The General Ledger (GL) contains numerous processes that ensure that OLE runs correctly. For users processing e-doc transactions, the most apparent of these processes are the generation of offsets and the posting of transactions to the balance tables. Other important General Ledger processes are less apparent to users. These processes ensure that transaction data are valid, that capitalization entries are created, and that indirect cost recovery and cost share transfers occur. OLE also offers related features such as sufficient funds checking and flexible offsets for institutions that want to utilize this functionality.

OLE will apply encumbrances and expenses to the General Ledger as a result of OLE implemented functionality for encumbrances, expenses, budget adjustments and transfers of funds. Real-time GL posting is made available, with certain GL entries updating their status through nightly “batch jobs”.

note.para: We continue to reconcile university financial integrations and OLE’s use of Budget vs. Actual (cash) balances in our coding efforts.

listitem.para: No GL entries for this form of “pre-order”

para.emphasis: Purchase Order, Purchase Order Amendment, other forms of PO

listitem.para: A final, “approved” Purchase Order will apply an encumbrance to the General Ledger as “pending”. During nightly batch jobs, the pending entry goes to “final”. Pending GL entries will be visible on the PO’s General Ledger Pending Entries tab, and be reflected in balance inquiries when “pending” or “all” transactions included.

Sample: pending GL entry from approved PO with default (OLE Sample Data/object code 9892- RESV OUTSTANDING ORDR EXTRNL ENCUMBRNCES, Credit offset to the purchase order Debit) Offset- not yet processed through nightly batch job

mediaobject.alt: Sample General Ledger Pending Entries from an Approved PO

listitem.para: Sample: PO that has processed to nightly batch job- no pending GL entries

mediaobject.alt: Sample General Ledger Pending Entries that has processed to nightly batch jobs

listitem.para: As PREQ’s are payments to vendors, any PREQ created with accounting lines will post to the GL as “pending” whether it has completed workflow or not (unlike PO which must be final/approved).
PREQ will reverse the encumbrance, as noted on the e-Doc, and apply the expense immediately.
Nightly batch jobs will take approved PREQ’s to final status, and also apply liabilities to the balance sheet.
Sample, PREQ with relieved encumbrance:

mediaobject.alt: Sample Process Items tab from a PREQ with Relieved Encumbrance

listitem.para: Sample: General Ledger Pending entries on approved PREQ (encumbrance and initial offset from PO are reversed. Expense applied with offset to Acct Payable/liability object code 9041):

mediaobject.alt: Sample General Ledger Pending Entries Tab from a PREQ with expenses applied

section.para: For all of the above transactions (Requisition to Purchase Order to Receiving to Payment Request), a user can see how the transactions post to the general ledger during the course of one day, i.e. if all docs created in same day, but including filter All on balance inquiry searches.

tip.para: OLE is cloud-based, allowing users to have multiple browser windows open. If a user wants to query multiple Account-Objects for available balances, while having a transaction open in another window- that user could jump through multiple queries or details in one window, then just copy/paste preferred Chart, Account, Object codes into the Accounting lines of an open transactional document in another window- Requisition, Purchase Order, Payment Request, Transfer of Funds etc.

section.title: GL Inquiries: Basic Information GL Inquiries Basic Information
Entering Lookup Criteria balance inquiries entering lookup criteria
section.para: After you select the desired inquiry, you are taken to the lookup criteria screen. The lookup criteria may display some default values, which you may change. To view all General Ledger balances on a specific account you need to enter just the chart and the account number. You can be more specific by including additional criteria. To view specific sub-accounts, object codes or sub-object codes you may enter these criteria. On some of the inquiry screens the balance type may be changed to view something other than actual balances. For example, to view budget transactions, you can change the balance type to either ‘CB’ (current budget), ‘BB’ (base budget), or ‘MB’ (monthly budget which may not be available on all accounts).
The following is an example of the lookup criteria screen for the General Ledger Balance Lookup.

mediaobject.alt: General Ledger Balance Lookup Screen Example: Fiscal Year 2010, Balance Type Code AC, Consolidation Option Consolidation, Amount View Option Monthly, Include Pending Ledger Entry No

section.para:
Click Search
when you have entered all necessary criteria and are ready to retrieve the balances.

section.title: Meaning of Dollar Accumulators balance inquiries dollar accumulators
section.para: The inquiries contain various dollar accumulators. The following describes the meaning of each of the amounts displayed in the inquiry results, and which inquiries contain the bucket type.

entry.para: The total amount of activity in this account for this balance type across all periods of the selected fiscal year. Appears in Cash Balances inquiry and the General Ledger Balance inquiry.
The total of all actual activity for a given balance line of the selected fiscal year. Appears in Available Balances inquiry and Balances by Consolidation inquiry.
The total of the beginning balance and the year-to-date balance. Appears in the Cash Balances inquiry.
The amount in this account for this balance type and object code at the beginning of the selected fiscal year. Appears in the General Ledger Balance inquiry.
The total of all activity for a given accounting period. These fields are labeled as the month to which they refer (July, August, September, etc.).
The current budget amount in this account for the selected fiscal year. Appears in Available Balances inquiry and Balances by Consolidation inquiry.
The amount of the encumbrance that has been closed. Appears in the Open Encumbrances inquiry.

The cumulative amount in this account for this balance type and object code that was carried forward from the previous fiscal year. Appears in the Cash Balance inquiry and the General Ledger Balance inquiry.
The total of all encumbrance activity for a given account for the selected fiscal year. Appears in Available Balances inquiry and Balances by Consolidation inquiry.
The dollar amount associated with a particular ledger entry. Appears in General Ledger Entry inquiry and Pending General Ledger Entry inquiry.
The amount of the original encumbrance. Subtracting the Closed Amount from the Open Amounts gives the amount of the encumbrance that is still outstanding. Appears in the Open Encumbrances inquiry.
The difference between the available budget and the actual amounts, plus encumbrances for an object code or category. Appears in Available Balances inquiry and Balances by Consolidation inquiry.

section.title: Drilldowns balance inquiries drilldowns
section.para: The various inquiries display their initial balances at different levels of aggregation. You may drill down into detail when there is the Drill Down link available, or if the amount or other attribute (e-doc, for example) is a hyperlink. The following illustrations show the types of drilldowns available in the inquiries.
You may drill down to the next level from the Drill Down link.
You may drill down to the entries that make up the total from the amount link.

mediaobject.alt: Drill Down by Total Amount Sample

section.para: You may drill down to the actual e-doc from the document Number link.

mediaobject.alt: Drill Down By Clicking on the hyperlinked items in the Results Lists - Document Number Sample

section.para: Drill down to pending entry

section.title: Include or Exclude Pending Entries, Unapproved Entries, and GL Entries balance inquiries including/excluding entries
section.para: Balance inquiries allow you to choose to include or exclude pending ledger entries. These entries have been generated by OLE documents that have not yet been posted through the GL accounting cycle. After a financial processing e-doc is saved, it generates pending ledger entries. These entries are considered pending until the document is disapproved (at which point they are removed) or the document is fully approved and the entries are posted to the General Ledger.

You can choose to exclude pending ledger entries (the default behavior), include all pending ledger entries, or include only those entries associated with documents that have been approved (documents that have reached 'Processed' or 'Final' workflow status).

note.para: Including all pending ledger entries in an inquiry can generate misleading results. Note that choosing to include all pending ledger entries in a balance inquiry can generate misleading results because saved documents may contain incomplete or unbalanced accounting entries. Choosing to view all pending ledger entries should be done with the understanding that unapproved entries may change drastically prior to actually posting or they may not post at all.

section.para: Refer to the following chart to identify the inquiry that applies to your analysis.

entry.para: Lists open encumbrance amounts only (no drilldown)

section.title: General Error Correction
section.para:
General Error Correction (GEC) document
Financial Processing General Error Correction (GEC) document
Select/Acquire
> Others
> General Error Correction
> General Error Correction
As an option, the General Error Correction (GEC) document is used to correct inappropriate or erroneous accounting string data for General Ledger entries generated from other financial transactions.

By consistently referring to the details of each transaction being corrected, the GEC preserves and maintains the audit trail. Fiscal officers and support staff, department and responsibility center are typical users of the GEC.

section.title: Document Layout
section.para: The GEC document only has the standard financial transaction document tabs and does not have any unique tabs of its own

note.para: For information about the standard tabs such as Document Overview, Notes and Attachments, Ad Hoc Recipients, Route Log, and Accounting Lines tabs, see Standard Tabs under OLE Basic Functionality.
The Year-End General Correction (YEGE) document is available only during the fiscal year-end close.

section.title:
Business Rules business rules General Error Correction (GEC) document
General Error Correction (GEC) document business rules

listitem.para: Debits must equal credits.
OLE automatically generates cash offset entries as defined by the information entered into the document.

section.para: The following object sub-types are prohibited on this document:

para.emphasis: Restricted object sub type in the GEC document

section.title: Routing General Error Correction (GEC) document routing
section.para: Fiscal Officers for all accounts must approve the GEC document. Additional approvals may be established within the institution's review hierarchy or set up through Ad Hoc routing. The document status becomes 'FINAL' when the required approvals are obtained and the transaction is posted to the G/L during the next G/L batch process.

section.title: Initiating a GEC Document General Error Correction (GEC) document initiating

listitem.para: Select General Error Correction from the Others submenu on the Select/Acquire tab.
A blank GEC document with a new document ID appears.
Complete the standard tabs.
The Ref Number is a required field on the GEC document. This field identifies the reference number of the document being corrected.

The Line Desc box is optional and can be used to enter a description specific to that line of the GEC. If left blank, the description from the Document Overview tab passes to the G/L for that line of the transaction.
The Ref Origin Code is a required field. This code identifies the system that created the transaction being corrected.

note.para: For information about the standard tabs such as Document Overview, Notes and Attachments, Ad Hoc Recipients, Route Log, and Accounting Lines, see Standard Tabs under OLE Basic Functionality.

listitem.para:
Click Submit
.
Review the General Ledger Pending Entries tab.
This document automatically generates cash offset entries to cash or fund balance object codes.
Review the Route Log tab.
The document is routed to the fiscal officer for each account used in the Accounting Lines. The Route Status shows 'ENROUTE'.

note.para: For information about the Route Log tab, see Route Log under OLE Basic Functionality.

listitem.para: Appropriate fiscal officers and organization reviewers approve the document.

note.para: For more information about how to approve a document, see Workflow Action Buttons under OLE Basic Functionality.

section.title: Example General Error Correction (GEC) document example
section.para: Supplies were charged to an incorrect account. Use the From section to move the expense (credit expense) from the incorrect account and the To section to charge expense to the correct account (debit expense). The correct expense is debited and the incorrect expense is credited. The GEC document allows users to easily make corrections to documents previously submitted and approved.

section.title: General Ledger Correction Process
section.para:
Select/Acquire
> Others
> General Ledger Correction Process
> General Ledger Correction Process

If an error is encountered during any part of the validation process, the associated document (s) are not posted. Instead, error records are placed in the ScrbErr file (For more information about this file and other files generated by the GL batch processes, see Accounting Cycle Files.) This file can be retrieved using a GL Correction Process document. This process allows for the manual correction of errors so the associated documents may be re-posted in a future batch cycle.

section.title: Accounting Cycle Files
section.para: The GL Correction Process document allows functional users to view accounting cycle files in the Origin Entry Group list.

mediaobject.alt: General Ledger Correction Process Document: Documents in System Tab

section.para: The following table describes these files based on the names displayed in the Origin Entry Group list.

entry.para: Year-end entries to populate assets, liabilities, fund balance, and inception-to-date balances for the new fiscal year. Includes open and expired accounts.
Year-end entries to populate asset, liability, fund balance, and inception-to-date balances for the new fiscal year. Closed accounts only.
Year-end entries to close income and expense to fund balance in the fiscal year ending.
Year-end entries to bring forward outstanding encumbrances to the new fiscal year.
Expired and closed accounts identified during data validation in 'Scrubber.'
Backup of all files from the Origin Entry directory that will be fed into 'Scrubber' for processing. Examples: GLCP, e-docs, PDP, etc.
Error correction and file uploads processed by the General Ledger Correction Process for input into the accounting cycle.
Valid entries from the 'Collector' (which shares 'Scrubber' validation and 'Demerger' logic). Notification of entries with errors was sent back to the submitting unit for re-processing.
Entries processed via the Enterprise Feed Upload link in OLE. Entries have not yet passed 'Scrubber' validation.
Pending ledger entries from GL e-docs. Created by the Nightly Out batch job.
Entries from check and ACH disbursements, cancels, and cancel-and-re-issues processed by the Pre-Disbursement Processor.
Errors found in the ICRPoster that did not update the ledgers.
All indirect cost recovery (ICR) entries generated from eligible posted transactions.
Year-end entries to revert and carry forward current budget according to the established reversion rules.
Errors found in the 'Main Poster' that did not update the ledgers.

Error transactions identified by 'Scrubber' plus valid transactions for the same document type, origin code, and document number pulled by the 'Demerger.' These entries are not passed on to the 'Main Poster.' This is the most common file used for GLCP for error correction.
Valid entries from the 'Demerger' after pulling entries for any documents with errors that will be passed on to the 'Main Poster.'
Sorted icrtrans file for input into the ICR poster.
Sorted scrbout2 file for input into the 'Main Poster.'
Sorted backup data used for validation in 'Scrubber.'
Errors found in the 'Reversal Poster' that did not update the ledgers.
All automated reversal entries selected for processing by the 'Reversal Poster.'

section.title: General Ledger Entry General Ledger Entry
section.para:
Select/Acquire
> Others
> General Ledger Entry
> General Ledger Entry Lookup

note.para: For general information about entering lookup criteria, interpreting dollar accumulators, drilling down into inquiries to see more detail, and including or excluding pending entries, see GL Inquiries: Basic Information.

section.para: The General Ledger Entry inquiry displays the individual transactions that make up the balance in an account. It is the same inquiry that can be displayed by drilling down into the General Ledger Balance report, but instead of drilling down from the General Ledger Balance screen you can go directly to this report by selecting it from the main Balance Inquires menu.
The drilldown pattern of this inquiry is as follows:

listitem.para: General Ledger Entry
E-Doc

section.title: Lookup Criteria
section.para: Fill in at least Fiscal Year, Chart Code, Account Number, and Fiscal Period or Fiscal Year and Document Number. The lookup criteria default to the current fiscal year, balance type of 'AC'(actuals), and the current fiscal period.

Use the lookup icon
as necessary to select the criteria. Select the desired Pending Ledger Entry Approved Indicator option Pending Ledger Entry Approved Indicator option . The Pending General Ledger inquiry offers two alternatives for including the pending ledger entries: the ability to include all pending entries by selecting All or only those pending entries that are fully approved by selecting Approved. Cancelled and disapproved pending entries are not pulled into the balance inquiry results.

section.title: Search Results
section.para: The inquiry results list the transactions that meet your lookup criteria. From here you can drill down into the e-doc that created the transaction.

mediaobject.alt: General Ledger Entry Lookup Results Sample

section.title: E-Doc Drilldown E-Doc Drilldown
section.para: Clicking the document number link from the General Ledger Entry inquiry results allows you to open the underlying e-doc which makes up the transaction. You may view, copy or perform error correction once the document is open, within the constraints of your existing OLE role(s). Note that no link will be displayed if the document originates from a system other than OLE.

section.title: Pre-Encumbrance
section.para:
Select/Acquire
> Others
> Pre-Encumbrance
> Pre-Encumbrance

The Pre-Encumbrance (PE) document may be used in OLE as a “Reserve Option” on a single or group of accounting lines- Account/Objects. An Account could be setup at the beginning of the year, with a Budget allocated to the Account-Object code. Either through Restricted Status or Sufficient Fund check options, or the use of the Pre-Encumbrance, an account could be temporarily restricted, allow spending up to a $/% limit, or be “pre-encumbered” without requiring a Purchase Order or Payment Request.

The Pre-Encumbrance (PE) document allows you to add encumbrances using an e-doc instead of relying on information from some system outside OLE. These transactions are for the use of the fiscal officers to earmark funds for which unofficial commitments have already been made, setting aside amounts for future anticipated expenses that might not otherwise be encumbered. The document can also be used to disencumber open encumbrances created with the PE document.

section.title: Document Layout
section.para: A PE document has its own unique tab called Pre-Encumbrance Details in addition to the standard financial transaction tabs.

note.para: For more information about the standard tabs, see Standard Tabs under OLE Basic Functionality.

section.title: Pre-Encumbrance Details Tab
section.para: The Pre-Encumbrance Details tab contains an optional Reversal Date field date. When entering an encumbrance, a reversal date may be entered to indicate when the system should automatically reverse the encumbrance. This date must not be earlier than the current date.

Encumbrances entered on a PE document without a reversal date must be reversed manually by processing another PE document and entering one or more accounting lines in the Disencumbrance section of the document.

entry.para: Optional. Enter the date when the system should automatically reverse the encumbrance. The date must not be earlier than the current date.

listitem.para: There must be at least one accounting line in the document.

Unlike other documents with more than one side, there is no relationship between the Encumbrance and Disencumbrance sections of accounting lines. Hence, there are no totals in the Accounting Lines tab of the document.
Only object codes with an object type code of Expenditure Not Expense (EE) or Expense Expenditure (EX) are allowed on this document.
Negative amounts are not allowed. Encumbrances and disencumbrances are both recorded as positive amounts.
OLE automatically generates offset entries, as defined by information entered into the document.

tip.para: If you are using the Sufficient Funds checking feature of OLE, remember that encumbrances are taken into account in the sufficient funds calculation.

section.title: Routing
section.para: The PE document routes based on the account numbers used on the document as follows:

listitem.para: The fiscal officer for each account must approve.
Organization review routing occurs for the organization that owns each account.
Sub-fund routing occurs based on the sub-fund of each account.

section.para: The document status becomes 'FINAL' when the required approvals are obtained and the transaction is posted to the G/L during the next G/L batch process.

listitem.para: Select Pre-Encumbrance from the Others submenu on the Select/Acquire tab.
A blank PE document with a new document ID appears.
Complete the standard tabs. Complete the Accounting Lines tab as follows:
Complete the Accounting Lines tab by entering information into the Encumbrance section, Disencumbrance section, or both.
Encumbrance Section: Accounting lines entered on the Encumbrance side of the document generate new encumbrances on the specified accounts.
Disencumbrance Section: Accounting lines entered on the Disencumbrance section of the document reverse existing encumbrances on the specified accounts.

Lines on the Disencumbrance section require a Ref Number which identifies the document number of the previous pre-encumbrance that needs to be removed. Disencumbrances entered in the PE document would only be used to remove an encumbrance previously established with a PE document.

note.para: For information about the standard tabs such as Document Overview, Notes and Attachments, Ad Hoc Recipients, Route Log, and Accounting Linestabs, see Standard Tabs under OLE Basic Functionality.

listitem.para: Complete the Pre-Encumbrance Details tab.

Click Submit
.
Review the General Ledger Pending Entries tab.
The pending entries include offset generation lines to a pre-defined reserve for Encumbrances object code.
Review the Route Log tab.

note.para: For information about the Route Log tab, see Route Log under OLE Basic Functionality.
For more information about how to approve a document, see Workflow Action Buttons under OLE Basic Functionality.

section.title: Fiscal Year Rollover (Year End Processes)
section.para: OLE uses KFS code for Purchasing and Accounts Payable (PURAP), the General Ledger (GL), Chart of Accounts (COA), and Financial Processing (FP) modules with some modifications. OLE repurposed the Pre Disbursement Processing (PDP) code used by KFS for payment disbursements. With OLE, the PDP is only used to extract data from approved invoices and credit memos to send in a feed to an institution’s financial system (KFS or another institutional financial systems such a Banner, PeopleSoft).
For OLE’s use, the KFS Fiscal Year (FY) process has been adapted to:

listitem.para: Create a new fiscal year, including new object codes
Roll open encumbrances from the current fiscal year to the new fiscal year, date set by library
Stop activity in the old year, with a date set by library
Re-encumber recurring orders at the beginning of each fiscal year, at an amount chosen by an operator (same as current year’s encumbrance: current year’s encumbrance +/- a percentage)

note.para: Temporary note: We believe this is new functionality (OLE-7193)

listitem.para: Reassign all open purchase orders on one account to another account, in batch

note.para: Temporary note: This need was defined by an OLE partner as part of their rollover process, but libraries will undoubtedly need it at other times, unconnected to rollover

section.para: Some features of the KFS FY Rollover process that are not needed by OLE partners but remain available are:

listitem.para: Allocate money in the new fiscal year based on the current fiscal year’s allocations (The assumption is that each library will set their allocation levels offline, and then load the final figures in via a Budget Adjustment document.)
Manage a 13th month which is handled by the university financial system
Produce financial statements as libraries need only a snapshot of orders and expenditures in a given year

para.emphasis: Jobs inherited from KFS for FY Rollover (See Batch Job Description for further description details)

entry.para: This job creates the beginning and cumulative balances for the next year.
This job purges transaction entries in the GL_PENDING_ENTRY_T table.

This process closes and carries forward pre-encumbrances and internal and external encumbrances into the new fiscal year. The process also carries forward pre-encumbrances for Contracts and Grants accounts. It examines all GL encumbrance entries for the fiscal year being closed. These entries are summarized by chart code, account number, sub-accountnumber, object code, sub-object code, and balance type. Each combination is considered as a unit of work in the application of the following business rules. The rules are divided into two categories—business rules associated with closing encumbrances and business rules associated with cost share carry forward.

Creates a gl_close_nominal_activity.data file in uazkf/prd/staging/gl/originEntry. Requires a manually-created gl_close_nominal_activity.done file in uazkf/prd/staging/gl/originEntry for the scrubber to run. See Closing Nominal Activity
creates a copy of current year
This job synchronizes three sets of tables:

listitem.para: GL_ENTRY_T to GL_ENTRY_HIST_T
GL_BALANCE_T to GL_BALANCE_HIST_T
GL_ENTRY_T to _GL_BALANCE_T

entry.para: applies the pending ledger entries, including any OLE-genereated entries, to the General Ledger.

This batch job copies table values that are specific to a fiscal year into another fiscal year. Generally this job is used to copy values in maintenance tables from the current fiscal year into the next fiscal year to prepare those tables for future use. Some modules, such as Budget Construction, may require that these tables be updated with next fiscal year's values well before the end of the current fiscal year.

section.title: Initial Setup Instructions and Settings
section.para: Set this parameter to indicate when the last day of your fiscal year is:

listitem.para: CURRENT_AND_LAST_YEAR

section.para: Its function is to control some data on poster report – set it only once for the initial OLE setup.
Populate these parameters:

listitem.para: NET_EXPENSE_OBJECT_CODE
NET_REVENUE_OBJECT_CODE

section.para: Each parameter should have one object code that will be used during rollover. They can either be object codes you use during regular processing or special ones you define specifically for rollover. If the latter, leave them inactive for most of the year and only activate them during the rollover process.
The Expense Object Code must have an object code type of EX or ES.
The Revenue Object Code must have an object code type of AS, CH or IN.
Populate these parameters:

listitem.para: OFFSET_OBJECT_CODE_FOR_EXTERNAL_ENCUMBRANCE
OFFSET_OBJECT_CODE_FOR_INTERNAL_ENCUMBRANCE
OFFSET_OBJECT_CODE_FOR_PRE_ENCUMBRANCE

section.para: Each parameter should have one object code of type=FB. You may want to create special object codes for these parameters (that is, codes you do not use for other purposes).
Populate the “object code” fields on each Chart document.

note.para: For additional information about the Chart document, see chart in this chapter.

section.para: Every chart has a series of “object code” fields on the Chart document that must be populated with existing object codes before rollover. They don’t do anything most of the year, but need to be populated with existing object codes before rollover.

note.para: Temporary note: Unclear if it matters what codes are used, so long as they exist and are active.

section.para: Populate these parameters:

listitem.para: REENCUMBER_RECURRING_FROM_DATE -- with the first date you created orders in your system
REENCUMBER_RECURRING_TO_DATE -- with a date far in the future

section.para: The REENCUMBER_RECURRING_ORDERS job can produce a large data file, and running the whole job at once may impact system performance for some sites. These parameters allow you to break the job into chunks. However, if you do not set them to something by default, the job will fail.
Supply entry description text, if desired, in this parameter:

listitem.para: BEGINNING_FUND_BALANCE_TRANSACTION_LEDGER_ENTRY_DESCRIPTION
GENERATED_TRANSACTION_LEDGER_ENTRY_DESCRIPTION

section.para: The text will be added to ledger entries created by the encumbrance closing process.
Set these balance types parameters to control what types of balances, if any, roll forward:

listitem.para: BALANCE_TYPES_TO_ROLL_FORWARD_FOR_BALANCE_SHEET
BALANCE_TYPES_TO_ROLL_FORWARD_FOR_INCOME_EXPENSE

section.para: Since many OLE libraries will not be rolling balances forward, only encumbrances, and also will not be running the “balanceForward” job, these parameters are moot for them.
Set one or both of these forward encumbrance parameters if you want to control which types of encumbrances roll forward:

listitem.para: FORWARD_ENCUMBRANCE_BALANCE_TYPE_AND_ORIGIN_CODE
FORWARDING_ENCUMBRANCE_BALANCE_TYPES

section.para: If you do not need to exclude specific types of encumbrances from rolling over, you can leave these parameters blank.
Check that these parameters are active:

listitem.para: ANNUAL_CLOSING_DOCUMENT_TYPE
ANNUAL_CLOSING_FUND_BALANCE_OBJECT_CODE
should contain your fund balance object code
ANNUAL_CLOSING_FUND_BALANCE_OBJECT_TYPE

section.title: Three Months Before End of Fiscal Year
section.para: Set the following two parameters to the current fiscal year:

listitem.para: ANNUAL_CLOSING_FISCAL_YEAR
SOURCE_FISCAL_YEAR

section.para: They control fiscal years covered by later jobs.
Set this parameter if desired:

listitem.para: OVERRIDE_TARGET_YEAR_DATA_IND

section.para: The parameter controls which mode the “FiscalYearMaker” batch process runs.
Setting options:

listitem.para: N=copies values to the new fiscal year without overwriting any values that already exist in the new year
Y=copies values to the new fiscal year and overwrites any values that already exist in the new year.

section.para: This setting may not affect OLE sites, since you will not have data in your new fiscal year until after rollover. But could be important if you have to run “FiscalYearMaker” more than once (for instance, to add a new account to the new fiscal year).
Set this parameter:

listitem.para: ALLOW_ENCUMBER_NEXT_YEAR_DAYS

section.para: This parameter allows you to start encumbering in the new fiscal year before rolling over.
Activate the object codes in the following two parameters ( if they are not already active):

listitem.para: NET_EXPENSE_OBJECT_CODE
NET_REVENUE_OBJECT_CODE

section.para: Run FiscalYearMakerJob
This job runs a series of steps in dependency order, populating tables in the background and creating object codes for the new fiscal year.
Clean up your data as much as you can.

Rollover problems can often be traced to specific documents that are Saved or Enroute. Sometimes, the autoDisapproveJob fails rather than move them to Disapproved status. The last couple of months of the fiscal year are a good time to try to resolve as many of them as possible.

section.title: When You Are Ready To Rollover
section.para: Take the following actions when you have completed the activity in the current fiscal year.
Set these two parameters:

listitem.para: ANNUAL_CLOSING_TRANSACTION_DATE
RUN_DATE

section.para: The values will be the date you are running rollover.
Set this parameter:

listitem.para: RECORD_COUNT_FUNCTIONALITY_LIMIT

section.para: This parameter is needed if you intend to manually edit the rollover data via the General Ledger Correction Process (GLCP) document. This parameter sets the maximum number of lines the GLCP document will display. All lines over the minimum set in the parameter will roll over, but the additional lines cannot be edited within the document. (The limit prevents the document size from becoming unmanageable.)
Set these parameters:

listitem.para: CURRENT_YEAR_UPPER
CURRENT_YEAR_LOWER

section.para: Set these parameters if you want the GL summary report to include data from both the old and new fiscal years. Setting this parameter is only necessary if you expect to be working simultaneously in both fiscal years for a period of time.
Set this parameter:

listitem.para: REENCUMBER_RECURRING_ORDERS

section.para: Set this parameter if you want recurring orders (such as on-going serials) re-encumbered in the new fiscal year. This only affects orders that have been unencumbered in the current fiscal year (because they were paid for). Recurring orders that already have an encumbrance are covered by the “encumbranceForward” job step.

If this job takes a long time to complete, or slows the system down, you can limit it by using the REENCUMBER_RECURRING_FROM_DATE and REENCUMBER_RECURRING_TO_DATE parameters. You would then need to run the job multiple times, once for each time period defined by the parameters.

The parameter can be set to calculate the new encumbrance based on either the original price on the PO, or the amount invoiced during the current fiscal year, plus or minus a dollar amount or a percentage.
Examples:

listitem.para: Invoice, + 2 %
Invoice, + 10 $

section.para: If you need to restrict creation of acquisitions documents in the system while are you are running rollover, run this job:

listitem.para: modulesLockJob

section.para: Staff will still be able to do lookups, but will not be able to initiate documents.

warning.para: It appears to be possible to approve existing documents while the modules are locked. But the documents may not be able to perform all their functions once approved. If you approve an invoice, for instance, while the modules are locked, it will be unable to create corresponding payment request documents. Warn staff not to approve saved documents during rollover.

section.para: If you want to auto-disapprove documents that are currently enroute, run this job:

listitem.para: autoDisapproveJob

section.para: This job disapproves open document types *except* for those listed in the YEAR_END_AUTO_DISAPPROVE_DOCUMENT_TYPES parameter
This job is optional. If documents are not disapproved, they will still roll over to the new fiscal year.
Related parameters:

listitem.para: YEAR_END_AUTO_DISAPPROVE_DOCUMENT_RUN_DATE -- specifies the date to run autoDisapproveJob

note.para: The format for this parameter is MM/DD/YYYY, even though the default value is 6/30/2010

listitem.para: YEAR_END_AUTO_DISAPPROVE_DOCUMENT_TYPES -- specifies document types not to be disapproved
YEAR_END_AUTO_DISAPPROVE_PARENT_DOCUMENT_TYPE -- specifies parent document types (by name) whose children should be disapproved

note.para: The default value for this parameter is: OLEFinancialProcessingTransactionalDocument
If you also want invoices to be disapproved, you have to add: OLEPurchasingAccountsPayableTransactionalDocument as a second value.

listitem.para: YEAR_END_AUTO_DISAPPROVE_DOCUMENT_CREATE_DATE -- job will only disapprove documents created on or before this date. This parameter lets you run the disapprove job without affecting any end-of-year documents.

note.para: The format for this parameter is MM/DD/YYYY, even though the default value is 6/30/2010

listitem.para: YEAR_END_AUTO_DISAPPROVE_ANNOTATION -- provides the text that will be put in the route log of disapproved documents

section.para: Set this parameter if desired:

listitem.para: SUB_FUND_GROUPS_FOR_INCEPTION_TO_DATE_REPORTING

section.para: This parameter allows you to define accounts that you want to carry all their balances forward each year (including income and expense). Accounts in the sub-fund groups designated here will carry forward any income and expense values into the new fiscal year. This happens for as long as the account is active.

This is really designed for accounts that reflect projects or activities that for whatever reason do not necessarily conform to the standard fiscal year. (For example, grants with an unusual grant year)

listitem.para: Schedule or run the populatePriorYearDataJob

section.para: This creates copies of both active and closed accounts and organizations, for use by the closing jobs.

listitem.para: Schedule or run organizationReversionCurrentYearAccountJob
Schedule or run organizationReversionPriorYearAccountJob

section.para: These two jobs are optional. Their purpose is to collect remaining budgets or cash and centralize them into a designated account. This would only be useful to sites that are allowed to carry money over.

listitem.para: Run reencumberRecurringOrdersJob

section.para: This job re-creates the encumbrances for recurring orders that have been unencumbered (by being paid in the current fiscal year).
This job works by producing an output file. You then load the file into a General Ledger Correction Process (GLCP) document. When submitted, the GLCP document should make the changes.
Once Submitted, the GLCP may take minutes to route before becoming Final. The job itself may take minutes or hours to run in the background.

listitem.para: Run nightlyOutJob, scrubberJob and posterJob, in that order

section.para: The encumbranceForwardJob has a dependency on these jobs. All three run as part of the nightly job schedule. So if you run encumbranceForwardJob first thing in the morning, you don’t need to run them manually. But if you run encumbranceForwardJob later in the day, you should run them manually to catch any transactions done so far that day.

listitem.para: Schedule or run encumbranceForwardJob

section.para: This job creates encumbrances for open orders in the new fiscal year. It does not relieve the encumbrance in the previous fiscal year. Like the reencumberRecurringOrdersJob above, this job works by producing an output file. You then load the file into a General Ledger Correction Process (GLCP) document. When submitted, the GLCP document makes the changes.

listitem.para: Schedule or run nominalActivityClosingJob

section.para: This job likewise produces a file, which you then submit via a GLCP. It closes the previous fiscal year for editing.
Related parameters:

listitem.para: NET_EXPENSE_OBJECT_CODE
NET_REVENUE_OBJECT_CODE
Schedule or run balanceForwardJob

section.para: We believe this job is optional – if you are loading new budget amounts via a Budget Amendment (BA) document, you may not need any balances brought forward
Like the previous jobs, it produces a data file, which must be submitted via a GLCP document

section.title: After Rolling Over
section.para: Set parameter to new fiscal year

listitem.para: FISCAL_YEAR
Run nightlyOutJob, scrubberJob and posterJob again

section.para: This ensures the new ledger updates have moved to approved status.
Check the results.
After rolling over, you should see the following results:

listitem.para: object codes for the new fiscal year (as a result of fiscalYearMaker)
encumbrances in the new fiscal year (as a result of encumbranceForward)
the encumbrances will still also exist in the previous fiscal year – encumbranceForward makes copies of the existing encumbrance entries, but does not delete the previous fiscal year entries
balances in the new fiscal year, if you ran balanceForward

section.para: If you do not see these results, check the log files for each job, and see if it lists failures. If so, you need to restart the process from the point of failure.
Inactivate the accounting periods from the old fiscal year.

listitem.para: Use the Accounting Period lookup on the Maintenance menu, and uncheck the “Active Indicator” checkbox in the appropriate document(s).

tip.para: Should you later need to make any last-minute changes in the previous fiscal year, you can reactivate the appropriate accounting period, make the change, and then deactivate it again.

section.para: Likewise, check the accounting periods for the new fiscal year, and make sure each is active.

note.para: For additional information about the Accounting Period document, see Accounting Period in this chapter.

section.para: Run the modulesUnlockJob to restore staff access, but only if you previously ran the modulesLockJob.
Deactivate the object codes in these two parameters (if they are special codes only used for rollover):

listitem.para: NET_EXPENSE_OBJECT_CODE
NET_REVENUE_OBJECT_CODE

section.para: If you want staff to still be able to post to the previous fiscal year, you must set these two parameters:

listitem.para: ENABLE_FISCAL_PERIOD_SELECTION_IND
FISCAL_PERIOD_SELECTION_DOCUMENT_TYPE (specify which doc types)

section.para: If you want to be able to retrospectively create accounts in the previous fiscal year, you must list those accounts in this parameter:

listitem.para: PRIOR_YEAR_ACCOUNTS_TO_BE_ADDED

section.para: Once the parameter has been updated, run the addPriorYearAccountsJob.
Change this parameter if you want to delete accounting data from your system that is older than x years:

listitem.para: PRIOR TO YEAR

section.para: Load your budget for the new fiscal year, via spreadsheet, using the Budget Adjustment document.

note.para: For additional information about the Budget Adjustment document, see Budget Adjustment in this chapter.

section.title: Rollover Checklist
section.para: Available here is a downloadable checklist of the steps needed to perform fiscal year rollover. For details of each step, see the full instruction above.
Rollover Checklist.

section.title: Closing Nominal Activity
section.para: The close nomincal activity process:

listitem.para: aggregates the revenues earned and expenses incurred during the year and calculates the difference,
posts the resultant deficit or surplus to the institution's net assets, and
resets the revenue and expense buckets to zero for the new fiscal year.

section.para: All GL balance entries for the fiscal year being closed are examined. These entries can be summarized by Chart of Accounts code, account number, sub-account number, object code, sub-object code, balance type, and object type. Each combination is considered as a unit of work in the application of the following business rules.

listitem.para: Actual expenses and actual revenues balance types are eligible for close.
Those representing expense and revenue object types are eligible for close.
The annual balances that do not have a zero balance are eligible.

If the unit of work qualifies for closing nominal activity, create a pending close nominal activity entry in an object code defined in the NET_EXPENSE_OBJECT_CODE or NET_INCOME_OBJECT_CODE parameters. An entry is also made to the corresponding fund balance offset.

section.title: Year End E-Docs
section.para: On the Select/Acquire tab, the Others submenu provides access to year-end versions of the following financial documents:

listitem.para: Budget Adjustment (YEBA)
Distribution of Income/Expense (YEDI)
General Error Correction (YEGEC)

note.para: This documentation does not provide a separate section for each individual year end e-doc because these e-docs are similar to each other and are similar to their regular e-doc counterparts. General information about the year-end e-docs is provided below. For information about business rules for each e-doc, see the section on its regular counterpart.

section.para: The Year-End documents are used to record transactions that occurred during a fiscal year, but were not recorded prior to the end of the final accounting period for that fiscal year. The standard versions of the OLE financial documents post the transaction to the current fiscal year and period during which the document is approved. The Year-End documents are posted to whatever fiscal period of the previous fiscal year is currently open to receive transactions (period 12 or 13 depending on the institution's posting schedule). fiscal officers and support staff, department, responsibility center, and campus administration staff are typical users of the Year-End documents.

The Year-End documents are used primarily in the period between the end of a fiscal year and the end of the closing period for that fiscal year. An OLE Superuser (likely a central administrator at the institution) determines when these documents become available and for how long they are active. In most cases they are available for only a brief window of time following the end of an institution's fiscal year, prior to final closing of that fiscal year.

section.title: Year End E-Doc Business Rules
section.para: Year-End documents inherit all the business rules of their regular document. For example, a Year-End Distribution of Income and Expense document uses the same business rules as the regular Distribution of Income and Expense document.

note.para: For more information about the non year-end documents, see the help documentation for the associated e-doc type.

listitem.para: Year-End documents route differently from their regular counterpart documents. Most notably they skip the fiscal officer level of routing and go directly to Org Review. The Year-End documents route as follows:
Organization review routing occurs for the organization that owns each account. See note below.
Sub-fund routing occurs based on the sub-fund of each account.
The document status becomes 'FINAL' when the required approvals are obtained and the transaction is posted to the G/L during the next G/L batch process.
Select the desired year-end document from the Others menu group on the Select/Acquire taab.
Log into OLE as necessary.
A blank Year-End document with a new document ID appears.
Complete the standard tabs and the other tabs specific to the document type.

note.para: For information about the standard tabs such as Document Overview, Notes and Attachments, Ad Hoc Recipients, Route Log, and Accounting Linestabs, see Standard Tabs under OLE Basic Functionality.

listitem.para:
Click Submit
.
Review the General Ledger Pending Entries tab.

Year-End documents generate General Ledger entries (including offsets) in the same way their regular counterpart documents do, but all these entries are posted to the open accounting period of the prior fiscal year, most often accounting period 13.
Review the Route Log tab.
The document is routed to Org Review for each account used in the Accounting Lines. The Route Status shows 'ENROUTE.'

note.para: For more information about the Route Log, see Route Log under OLE Basic Functionality.

listitem.para: Appropriate organization reviewers must approve the document.

note.para: For more information about how to approve a document, see Workflow Action Buttons under OLE Basic Functionality.

section.title: Standard COA E-Docs
section.para:
Maintenance
> Chart of Accounts
> Account
> Chart of Account Links

The Chart of Accounts submenu on the Maintenance tab offers access to several Chart of Accounts e-docs that allow users to update reference tables that provide key structure for the tracking and storage of financial data.

section.title: Managing COA Documents
section.para: Kuali OLE relies on a variety of Chart of Accounts (COA) tables to function. These tables define the attributes and values used by the system to validate transactions. They also control the often complex relationships between elements in the Chart of Accounts that must be leveraged for internal and external reporting. For example, tables store basic information such as the sub-fund groups to which new accounts may be assigned and the calendar month that correlates to the first month of your institution's fiscal year. This type of flexibility is one of the features that make OLE a highly configurable application.
A note on language:

para.emphasis: Libraries more often call it (or it equates to):

entry.para: Material type and/or order type and/or subject

section.para: This section presents information and instructions for viewing records in the COA tables and using e-docs to maintain these tables.

note.para: OLE also delivers a feature to add extension tables if your institution wants or needs to record additional Chart of Accounts attributes that are not part of the base system. OLE extended attributes may be free text fields or may have an associated reference table to supply valid values. The data dictionary can be configured by your technical staff in the following manner:

listitem.para: An extended attribute displays on the associated e-doc
An extended attribute can be made required or optional
An extended attribute can be available as search criteria and/or in the search results in a lookup.

note.para: For more information about extended attributes, see Extended Attributes under OLE Basic Functionality.

section.title: Initiating Chart of Account Structures
section.para: Libraries must set up a parent (university) chart, organization, object code and account first. This must be done by directly inserting the data into the database and not from the OLE user interface.
See:

listitem.para: OLE Demonstration Library - Chart of Accounts and GL on the wiki for a demonstration of how KFS sets up budgets and Charts of Accounts as well as a Configuration Workbook template that is used to assist KFS users in their set up.
Populating a Chart of Accounts (requires KIS credentials, see Getting Started with OLE)

section.para: In the OLE Test and Demo environments, OLE users are welcome to begin creating a new Chart, Organizations, and CoA structures to test a setup, but are encouraged to default to the OLE “IU-University Chart” as the parent of any new structures (primary object codes defined).

section.title: Creating Funds: OLE Chart of Accounts
section.para: Chart of Accounts (COA) is the set of controlling tables that define financial information, such as the codes and coding structures within OLE, including attributes like Accounts, Organizations, and Object Codes. The COA module exists primarily to support and validate entries into the General Ledger (G/L).OLE is leveraging the coding, processing and structures of the KFS Chart of Accounts, which includes:

listitem.para: Fiscal Year, Accounting Period
Charts
Account, Fund Group, Sub-Fund Group, Account Global; Account Delegate
New: Sufficient Funds checking
Sub-Account, Financial Reporting Code
Object Codes, Object Global, Sub-Objects, Sub-Object Global, Object Level/Consolidation
Organizations, Responsibility Center, Organization Review
Project Codes
Chart of Accounts Maintenance Documents (Attributes/Controlled Value Lists)

section.para: A Chart is the primary or parent structure, to which 1:N (Many) Organizations belong. Accounts and Object belong to a single Chart. Budgets are then applied to combined Account-Object structures. Accounts may have sub-accounts, and Object may have sub-objects for further division and reporting.
In OLE Library sample Chart, Organization, Account, Object and Budget (using Chart “BL”):

section.title: Global COA Documents
section.para: Some COA documents (Account, Object Code, and Sub-Object Code) allow you to assign identical values to multiple 'objects' on a single document known as a global document.
To initiate a global document, select the desired document from the Chart of Accounts menu group on the Maintenance tab and enter the appropriate data.

note.para: For more information about a specific global document, see the subsection for that e-doc.

section.title: Edit List of xxx Tab Documents edit tab
section.para:
The global documents include the Edit List of xxx (where xxx is an attribute name) tab which allows you to add the attributes you want to modify. This can be done by looking up attributes to include on your document and using the Look Up / Add Multiple xxx lookup
or by adding the values manually one at a time. At least one item must be selected on the Edit List of xxx tab.

note.para: For more information about a specific global document, see the subsection for that e-doc.

It is important to note that all global documents do not behave in exactly the same way. For accounts and organization reversion, the global document can only update accounts and organization reversion rules. For object and sub-object codes, the global document allows you to create new and update codes. The Account Delegate Global document is unique in that it deactivates all existing delegation for accounts on the document and replaces it with the delegation on the document.

section.title: Account Account
section.para:
Maintenance
> Chart of Accounts
> Account
> Account
> Account Lookup
> Account

The Account document is used to create new accounts or to edit or copy existing accounts. An account is used to identify a pool of funds assigned to a specific university organizational entity for a specific purpose. Accounts are the fundamental building blocks of OLE Financial Transactions. Financial Transactions are always associated with one or more accounts. Accounts and Objects are assigned budgets, and provide the financial framework for budgeting, balance inquiries, and encumbering funds for Purchase Orders, or paying vendors via Payment Requests.

An account has many different attributes associated with it that often determine how OLE allows you to use that account in transactions. It also has attributes associated with it that aid in reporting or drive special processes, such as indirect cost calculation.

The Account document comes with a global document option where you may make certain changes to a group of accounts at once. . Key attributes for OLE Accounts are: Stewardship Requirement, Legacy Fund Code, Fund Group & Sub-Fund group. Each can be used in the future for queries, extracts and reporting as additional “sorts”. The feature of the Account Global document is explained in the section following the Account document.

The Account document has six account specific tabs: Account Maintenance, Account Responsibility, Guidelines and Purpose, Account Description, Stewardship Requirements, and Legacy Fund Codes tabs which group related attributes together.

section.title:
Account Maintenance Tab Account Maintenance Tab
Account Account Maintenance Tab
section.para: The fields on this tab define the various account attributes which are used in the application of business rules for transactions using the account, reporting options, approval routing, etc.

entry.para:
Required. Enter the code or search for it from the Chart lookup
. Uniquely identifies a single chart of accounts. The COA is the set of controlling tables that define financial information, such as the codes and coding structures within Kuali Financial System (OLE), including attributes like Accounts, Organizations, and Object Codes. The COA module exists primarily to support and validate entries into the General Ledger (G/L).

note.para: Though each Account is associated with one Chart, you can allow your accounts to be used by multiple charts, by setting the system's ACCOUNTS_CAN_CROSS_CHARTS_IND parameter to Y.

entry.para: Required. Enter the unique number to identify a pool of funds assigned to a specific institution entity for a specific function.

note.para: You may restrict the account prefix by the use of the PREFIXES parameter. For example, you may configure the parameter to reject account numbers beginning with '3' or with '00.

entry.para: Required. Enter the familiar title of a specific account

Required. Enter the number for the owner of the account, or search for it from the Organization llookup
. Represents a unique identifier assigned to units within an institution.

Required. Select the physical campus on which the account is located from the Campus list, or search for it from the lookup
.
Represents the physical location of the account.
Required. Enter the date when the account became effective.

note.para: An account may be used on financial transactions before its effective date.

entry.para: Optional. Enter the date when the account expires. Business rules on transactions may prevent the use of expired accounts, or provide warnings when an expired account is being used.

Must be equal to or greater than the current date and cannot be before the Account Effective Date. If it is not blank, the continuation Chart of Accounts code and continuation account number are required.

Required. Enter the postal code assigned by the US Postal Service for the city where the account is managed, or search for it from the Postal Code lookup
.
Required. Enter the city where the account is managed.

Required. Enter the code for the state where the account is managed, or search for it from the State lookup
.
Required. Enter the street address where the account is managed.
Optional. Select the check box if the account activities occur off-campus; clear the check box if they do not.
Optional. Select the check box if the account is closed; clear the check box if it is open.
Closing an account is more permanent than expiring - no transactions can use a closed account and a closed account can only be re-opened by a system supervisor.

Required. Select from the Account Type list or search for it from the lookup
Examples used to categorize accounts for reporting purposes might include 'Fee Remissions Accounts' or 'Equipment Accounts.'
A code that categorizes or groups accounts for reporting purposes.

Required. Enter the code which relates an account to a fund, or search for it from the Sub-Fund Group lookup
. Examples are continuing education accounts, scholarships and fellowships, and general funds.
A designation of an account specific to fund accounting.

Enter the vendor associated with the Deposit Account, or search for it from the Vendor lookup
. This field is NOT allowed unless Sub Fund Group selected equals “Clearing/Revolving” or “Deposit”, and then it is required.
University Account Number associated with the Library Account. Ensures financial data is matched correctly to the University Account in the enterprise-wide financial system.
Required. Select the account restricted status code from the Account Restricted Status list. This code indicates whether funds in the account are:
T = Temporarily restricted R = Restricted U = Unrestricted
Restricted (R) and Temporarily Restricted (T) statuses will prevent staff from using accounts to purchase or pay for library materials.

If it is 'T,' then an account restricted status date is required. If the sub-fund associated with the account has a restricted status code, then that number pre-fills the field, in which case it is not editable. If the code on the sub-fund is blank, the Restricted Status Code field on the Account document must be completed.
Optional. Enter the date if the accounts restricted status code above is 'T.' This date signifies when the funds are targeted to become unrestricted.
If the Account Restricted Status Code is T (Temporarily Restricted), then this field becomes required and the date signifies when the funds are targeted to become unrestricted.

Optional. Select the Chart of Account code from the Chart list for the account designated to receive income generated from an endowment account or for the guarantee account for an underwrite for Contracts and Grants accounts.

Optional. Enter the account designated to receive income generated from an endowment account or the guarantee account for an underwrite for Contracts and Grants accounts, or search for it from the Account lookup
.

section.title:
Account Responsibility Tab Account Responsibility Tab
Account Account Responsibility Tab
section.para: The fields on this tab define the individuals responsible for the account as well as continuation account information and Sufficient Funds parameters.

entry.para:
Required. Enter the name of the fiscal officer, or search for it from the lookup
.

The Fiscal Officer is a person who is trained and hired for the purpose of providing fiscal, policy, and internal control management of all funds in a unit. They are responsible for ensuring that processes and related controls have been established to achieve the mission and objectives of their organization(s).

Optional. Enter the name of the account supervisor, or search for it from the lookup
. The supervisor oversees the management of the account at a higher-level than the fiscal officer, but rarely receives any direct requests for action from OLE. The account supervisor cannot be the same as the fiscal officer or the account manager.

The Account Supervisor will be the leader of the organization in which the account resides. In an academic unit this would probably be the Dean, in an administrative unit it would be the Vice President.

Optional. Enter the name of the account manager, or search for it from the lookup
. The account manager has the responsibility for ensuring that funds are spent and managed according to the goals, objectives and mission of the organization, to ensure that the funds are being spent according to a budgeted plan and that the allocation of expenditures is appropriate to the function identified for the account.

The Account Manager is the person who through their actions, their position, or the budgeting process of the Dean or Vice President has direct responsibility for how funds are spent and managed. Examples would be a principal investigator who received a grant or contract, an academic person who received internal research funds from the Dean, or a Director of a non-academic department.

Optional unless the account has an expiration date, in which case it is required. Enter the chart code for the continuation account, or search for it from the Chart lookup
. The field is required if the account has an expiration date.

Optional unless the account has an expiration date, in which case it is required. Enter the account that accepts transactions which are being processed on the account after the account expiration date, or search for it from the Account lookup
.
Income Stream Chart of Accounts Code

Optional. Select the Chart of Accounts for the income stream account from the Chart list, or search for it from the Chart lookup
. Parameters control when the income stream chart of accounts code and income stream account number are required.

Optional. Enter the account which has been designated to receive any offset entries from the account in order to balance responsibility center activity from the Account list or search for it from the lookup
.

The account designated to receive general fund income as part of the budget process for institutional funds, or the account designated to receive income from the sponsoring agency on contract and grant funds. When Budget Adjustments that involve accounts with different income stream accounts are made, OLE can be configured to create an automated Transfer of Funds transaction to properly adjust cash between those income stream accounts.

Optional. Select the check box to indicate that the account uses object presence control. Clear the check box if it does not. Object presence control requires that an object code be budgeted for the account before it can be used on an actual or encumbrance transaction.
If checked, requires that an Object Code be budgeted for the account before it can be used on an actual or encumbrance transaction.

Optional. Enter the percent variance to be used to compare the amount encumbered on the order to the amount invoiced by the vendor. If the difference between these two amounts is greater than the percent entered in this field a warning will appear on the invoice when it is submitted. This warning can be overwritten.

Optional. Enter the amount variance to be used to compare the amount encumbered on the order to the amount invoiced by the vendor. If the difference between these two amounts is greater than the amount entered in this field a warning will appear on the invoice when it is submitted. This warning can be overwritten.

tip.para: Both Threshold Percentage and Threshold Amount can be used if the user wants to see over a certain Threshold Percentage variance but only if it’s over a certain Threshold Amount. (Example: User wants to see anything over a 10% variance, but only if it’s over $100.)

section.title:
Guidelines and Purpose Tab Guidelines and Purpose Tab
Account Guidelines and Purpose Tab
section.para: The fields in the Guidelines and Purpose tab collect text description that provide details relating to the type of expenses that should be charged to the account, the source of its income, and the account's overall purpose.

mediaobject.alt: Account Document Guidelines and Purpose Tab

entry.para: Required unless the account expiration date is before the current date. Enter the text describing the type of expenditures that take place in the account. It should also explicitly state those expenditures that are not allowed in the account.

Required unless the account expiration date is before the current date. Enter the text describing the types of income (source of funds) that take place in the account. It should also explicitly state those revenues that are not allowed in the account.
Required. Enter the text describing the overall purpose of the account and the function it supports.

section.title:
Account Description Tab Account Description Tab
Account Account Description Tab
section.para: The Account Description tab contains optional information relating to the physical location of the account.

entry.para: Optional. Enter additional campus description if desired on the account.
Optional. Enter additional organization description if desired on the account.
Optional. Enter responsibility center description if desired on the account.

section.title: Stewardship Requirements Tab
section.para:
Stewardship Requirements have been added as metadata to be used in future workflows and routing (think: book plating, donors, etc.) This tab is repeatable- do not forget to use the Add
button to commit new Stewardship Requirements to the Account.

entry.para: Note related to the stewardship requirement.

section.title: Legacy Fund Codes Tab
section.para:
Legacy Fund Codes are added to assist libraries with migrating from legacy systems and combined fund code strings (which had fiscal year, account, and object information). This tab is repeatable- do not forget to use the Add
button to commit new Legacy Fund Codes to the Account.

mediaobject.alt: Account Document Legacy Fund Codes Tab

entry.para: Uniquely identifies legacy systems’ fund codes
Note related to the legacy fund code

section.title: Sufficient Funds Check tab
section.para: Sufficient funds checking is an option that can be used to stop the processing of e-doc transactions when an account does not have a balance large enough to cover expense transactions.

Sufficient funds checking can be established on an account-by-account basis. If the Transaction Process Sufficient Funds Check option on an account is checked and the Account Sufficient Funds Code is set to a value other than 'N' (no checking), then the account is checked for sufficient funds by OLE.
Sufficient Fund Check (SFC) operates differently on encumbrances vs. expenditures:

Encumbrances check against Free Balances (Budget - invoices (liabilities) [pending included] - expenditures [pending included] - encumbrances [pending included], occurs when encumbrances is pending (when requisition created/accts and costs assigned)
Expenditures check against Cash Balance (Budget - expenditures [pending included]) - when Payment Request created (pending).
The sufficientFundsAccountUpdateJob, which can be scheduled or run on demand, evaluates the pending ledger entries to determine whether or not they affect sufficient funds.

note.para: For more information about how to run this batch job, see Schedule under Administrative Functions.

mediaobject.alt: Account Document Sufficient Funds Check Tab

entry.para: Required. Select the code that indicates what level the account is going to be checked for sufficient funds in the transaction processing environment from the Account Sufficient Funds list. The choices are: A = Account C = Consolidation L = Level O = Object Code H = Cash N = No Checking
Optional. Select the check box if sufficient funds check should be performed on the account.
Identifies the type of encumbrance or expense, i.e., "over" or "under".
Coded selection choice of # (for Amount) or % (for Percentage).
Enter a value to be checked when encumbering the account on purchase orders.
Enter a value to be checked when paying the account on payment requests.
When the sufficient fund amount has been reached, you may select what will occur:

listitem.para: Block user: Transaction cannot go through
Warning: User gets warning message: “Account #xxxxx, has SFC (type) checking, and (accounting line) exceeds available balance thresholds.”
Routing: Route to the identified Fiscal Officer on Account for Approval.
Notifications: Transactions occur, but Fiscal Officer is notified of threshold being exceeded (to take corrective action, moving budgets etc.).

section.title: Business Rules Account business rules for
section.para: The Employee Type for the Financial-AQ4, Financial-AQ5, Accounting-AQ4 Fiscal Officer, Account Supervisor, and Account Manager must be 'P (Professional)' and the Employee Status must be 'A (Active).

The following rules apply to closing an account:
closing an account, business rules for

listitem.para: You must select an account active indicator: closed.
Account expiration date must be the current date or earlier
A continuation account number must be provided.
Only fully-approved Accounts (like other OLE documents) will display in Account Lookup inquiries or future Available balance inquiries.
The account must meet all the following criteria:
expires on or before the current date
has no budget balance
has no pending ledger entries
has no open encumbrances

has no asset, liability, or fund balances other than the fund balance object code defined for this account's chart and the process of closing income and expense into fund balance must take the fund balance to zero.
Only a system supervisor user can reopen a closed account.

section.title: Routing Account routing
section.para: The document routes to the fiscal officer for the account indicated on the document. If the document edits an existing account and includes a change to the value of the Fiscal Officer field, the document routes first to the current fiscal officer and then to the newly designated fiscal officer.

listitem.para: The document routes to the Org Reviewer based on the organization assigned to the account.
The document routes to the Chart Manager based on the chart assigned to the account.
Accounts route to the University Chart Manager for final approval.
As an OLE User, the Account Supervisor receives an FYI copy of the document.

section.title: Implementation Information
section.para: Every account requires one and only one fiscal officer. This cannot be a generic role but a real person who can take action on the account (every financial document that uses the account will route to the fiscal officer). If the person assigned as the fiscal officer leaves the institution, the job may be reassigned to another person.
You assign a fiscal officer directly to the account. You do not need to do anything from the “Identity Admin” section (KIM documents) on the Admin tab.

note.para: For additional instructions on assigning roles and permissions locally, see the draft document: Kuali Identity Management and OLE.

section.title: Account Global Global Account
section.para:
Maintenance
> Chart of Accounts
> Account
> Account Global
> Account Global

note.para: For general information about accessing and working with global documents, see Global COA E-Docs.

section.para: The Account Global document is used to assign identical attributes to multiple accounts on a single document. This could be used at initial implementations, or when needing to apply attributes for future reporting and extract. The same rules and options apply to Account Global documents as to Account e-docs, but with some restrictions on fields, and more routing/workflow.

section.title: Document Layout
section.para: The Account Global document contains the Global Account Maintenance screen and Edit List of Accounts tab.

section.title:
Global Account Maintenance Tab Global Account Maintenance Tab
Global Account Global Account Maintenance Tab
section.para: The Global Account Maintenance tab works the same as the Edit Account Maintenance tab of the Account document except that it contains only the fields that can be modified from this tab. There are no required fields in this tab. Instead, you only need to complete the fields that you want to update on the selected accounts. If an account attribute is to remain as is, leave that field blank.

mediaobject.alt: Account Global Global Account Maintenance Tab

note.para: For more information about how to complete the Global Account Maintenance tab, see Account Maintenance Tab.

section.title:
Edit List of Accounts Tab Edit List of Accounts Tab
Global Account Edit List of Accounts Tab
section.para:
There are two ways to populate the accounts that you want to update globally in the Edit List of Accounts tab. One is by manually entering or selecting one object code at a time from the normal Account lookup
, the other is by using a special multiple value lookup called the Look Up / Add Multiple Account Lines
to return multiple values.

note.para: For more information about the two types of lookup, see Field Lookup and Multiple Value Lookup under OLE Basic Functionality.

section.title: Business Rules business rules Global Account
section.para: The Account Global document is subject to the same business rules as the Account document. In addition, at least one account must be selected on the Edit List of Accounts tab.

note.para: For the information about the Account document business rules, see the Business Rules for the Account.

section.title: Routing routing Global Account
section.para: The Account Global document routes to the Chart Manager for every chart represented in the accounts being modified, and then to the University Chart Manager.

section.title: Initiating an Account Global Document global account document, initiating a
Using Look Up / Add Multiple Account Lines

To add multiple accounts to the Edit List of Accounts tab, click the Look Up / Add Multiple Account Lines lookup

Enter the desired search criteria to search for the accounts you want to include and click Search

After the result is returned, select check boxes to make your account selection and click Return Selected
.
The selected accounts are returned to the Edit List of Accounts tab.

Click Submit
.

listitem.para: Complete the Global Account Maintenance tab.

To add one account at a time, enter the values or use the Account lookup
.

Enter the desired search criteria to search for the accounts you want to include and then click Search
